President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu are holding what is expected to be their final meeting as heads of government on Wednesdayâ€”and there is every reason to expect that this one in New York, at the United Nations General Assembly, will be as fruitless as previous encounters. It is no secret that U.S.-Israel relations have become volatile and tense over the past eight years, with Obama and Netanyahu sparring over Israeli settlements and the all-but-moribund peace process, Iranâ€™s nuclear program, and the uprisings of the Arab Spring. But the likelihood of a sputtering end to the Barack-and-Bibi relationship does lead one to ask: Which of the two candidates who are running to replace Obama next Januaryâ€”Hillary Clinton or Donald Trumpâ€”might do somewhat better in restoring the U.S.-Israel relationship and pushing for peace? Story Continued Below Trump surrogate and former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani claimed at the Republican convention that Netanyahu and other government ministers favored Trump. Our sources say the Israeli security cabinet is divided but on the whole views Clinton as the safer course. There is, in any event, no doubt that the governing Likud Party has become closely aligned with Republicans in recent years, and that Netanyahu was betting on a Mitt Romney victory four years ago. â€œThe notion that they donâ€™t intervene in our politics and we donâ€™t intervene in theirs is pure nonsense,â€ as Aaron David Miller, a Middle East negotiator for successive U.S. administrations, has put it. â€œNetanyahu has clearly made his preferences clear on the Republican side.â€ But Netanyahu is himself often second-guessed by Israelâ€™s national security elites. And the answer to the question of who really would be better for a future U.S.-Israel alliance, a President Clinton or a President Trump, requires starting with a more basic issue: What does it mean to be a good ally to Israel? The current Israeli government seems to think that a good American ally would stop nagging Jerusalem about West Bank settlements, forget about the Israel-Palestine peace process, provide a blank check for security assistance, use military force in the region more readily, tear up the nuclear deal with Iran, and also supply weapons for Israel to strike Iran unilaterally if it thought it was necessary at some point. Hillary Clinton certainly would not follow this agenda to the letter; in that sense, her administration might well share some of Obamaâ€™s priorities. She clearly values the U.S.-Israel alliance highly, she is committed to Israelâ€™s security, and she has credibly promised to fend off diplomatic efforts that Israelis see as â€œdelegitimizingâ€ the Jewish state whether at the U.N., through sanctions, boycotts or punitive disinvestment. At the same time, she has confirmed that the peace process and a two-state solution will be central to her Israel policies. And she promises to safeguard, not tear up, the nuclear deal with Iran. Safeguarding means holding Iran to its terms and being prepared, as Obama promised in spring 2012, to use military force if needed to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Many Israelis derided Obamaâ€™s commitmentâ€”wrongly, in our view. But Clintonâ€™s credibility regarding the use of force should not be in doubt. On balance, we think, she would be a better president in the long run for Israel. Hereâ€™s why. If Jerusalem hopes for an American president to renege on the nuclear deal, Trump may well be their man. He has certainly bragged about his history of walking away from agreements. What happens then, however, is a question for which Trump has no convincing answer. Some of his advisers point to Richard Nixonâ€™s â€œmadmanâ€ theory of how to frighten rivals with the unpredictability of American leadership. But Nixon, whatever his other faults, was a shrewd geo-strategist (and he had Henry Kissinger by his side). Trump, judging by his erratic and impulsive behavior on just about any given day of this campaign, seems far too close to the madman template for anyoneâ€™s comfortâ€”least of all a small Middle Eastern state that depends on a steadiness of commitment from its American protector. Steadiness is one of the last words that come to mind when thinking about Trumpâ€™s various statements about Israel and the Palestinians. He could embrace something resembling neutrality and demand a return on U.S. assistanceâ€”signature Trump foreign policy themesâ€”or, alternatively, as he put it, he could be "the most pro-Israel president ever.â€ This uncertainty about his instincts does not bode well for alliance management. Indeed, his innate isolationism and nativist demagoguery portend two kinds of trouble for U.S. relations with Israel. First, Trump would enter office as the only genuinely isolationist president since the 19th centuryâ€”an unsettling prospect for Israel, which depends heavily on U.S. internationalism (and an experience that Israel, which is only 68 years old, has never had). Although not, as a rule, philosophically inclined, Trump has expressed a coherent view of international relations as fiercely transactional and zero sum. This view extends to alliances, as he made clear in a New York Times interview in which he explicitly disavowed Americaâ€™s Article 5 guarantee to defend NATO allies including Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. â€œIf we cannot be properly reimbursed for the tremendous cost of our military protecting other countries, and in many cases the countries Iâ€™m talking about are extremely rich â€¦ Then yes, I would be absolutely prepared to tell those countries, 'Congratulations, you will be defending yourself.â€â€™ In the world according to Trump, alliances such as NATO are inherently bad arrangements for the United States because the country is defending European allies who have little capacity to reciprocate, and who are unwilling to adequately pay for their protection. Likewise, maintaining a nuclear umbrella over South Korea and Japan seems to be a foolish and dangerous entanglement when those countries could just as well develop and deploy nuclear weapons themselves. And, of course, â€isolationismâ€ is a mild term for what Trump conceives as the proper relationship between the U.S. and its southern neighbor. Perhaps Trump will make an exception to his expectation of a â€œreturn on investmentâ€ for commitment to allies, and he will stand by Israel no matter what it can or cannot do for the U.S. in return. If so, however, it would be out of character. Second, Trumpâ€™s invective against Muslims and other immigrant communities might appear in sync with Israeli hard-linersâ€”the GOP nominee has indeed pointed to Israelâ€™s security barrier and security profiling of Muslims as models for his own Great Wall on the Mexican border and promised ban on Muslims entering the country. But if Israelâ€™s government really prefers Trump on this basis, this will drive another wedge between Israel and American Jews. Most American Jews are politically liberal, and they are particularly allergic to fear-mongering rhetoric against minorities. The experience of millennia has taught them that security for diaspora communities depends on a general climate of liberal tolerance. When demagogues single out minorities, Jews have to ask themselvesâ€”are we next? So, to take a small but telling example, when Trump has said that â€œmy Jewsâ€â€”presumably his employeesâ€”used to say â€œMerry Christmas,â€ and implies that his presidency will usher in a new era in which â€œHappy Holidaysâ€ will be a euphemism of the past, American Jews are not amused. The fact is, the U.S.-Israel alliance needs to be nurtured for the long haul, which means facing up to its real problems and reinforcing its moral foundations. It is wrong to think that the problems between Obama and Netanyahu have been determined by the personalities of the two leaders. Generational transformation on both sides has deepened strategic differences over the best way to manage a fragile regional balance of power, Palestinian political aspirations, and the increasingly anarchic conditions in the region. Israel is becoming more religious and less democratic. The United States is becoming more diverseâ€”this, after all, is what Trumpâ€™s followers are angry aboutâ€”and, arguably, more liberal. Surveys of young Israeli Jews show a sharp decline in support of Israelâ€™s identity as a democratic state, from 26.1 percent in 1998 to 14.3 percent today. The growing religious nationalist population is becoming increasingly powerful in Israeli politics and society, including the Israel Defense Force. In 1990, 2.5 percent of officer candidates self-identified as religious, compared with 26 percent in 2008. Young Americans, in contrast, are more liberal than their parents on matters related to Israel-Palestine. A recent Pew Survey indicated that 57 percent of self-styled â€œliberal Democratsâ€ sympathized with Palestinians more than Israelâ€”at a time when younger Democrats are more and more likely to call themselves liberal. Politics in both countries appear to be tracking these trends. Last May, Netanyahu fired Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon for defending a senior officerâ€™s right to criticize the government. Rather than seek to shore up his coalition by replacing him with a center-left figure, Netanyahu opted for the far-right wing Avigdor Lieberman as defense minister, creating what Israeli columnist Nahum Barnea has called â€œthe most radical government â€¦ in Israeli history.â€ Meanwhile, as Guiliani has contended, it may well be right that the Democratic Partyâ€™s leftward movement could bring additional tensions to relations with Israel. Bernie Sanders supporters on the Democratic Platform Committee failed in the effort to include language more harshly critical of the Israel occupation of the West Bank. There is little doubt, however, that this represented the views of many of his younger supporters. *** What can be done to revive the U.S.-Israel relationship, under either a President Clinton or President Trump? In our recent book on U.S.-Israel relations, we suggest that one approach would be to negotiate a formal alliance enshrined in a treaty that would specify mutual responsibilities. The U.S. would undertake a legally binding commitment to defend Israel from attack, particularly by Iran. Although the White House has already declared this commitment publicly, a solemn treaty obligation would inject it with greater credibility in Iranian as well as Israeli eyes. To underscore the depth of obligation, the U.S. could deploy a tripwire forceâ€”as it long did in the Asia and Europeâ€”to ensure that Israelâ€™s adversaries understood that an attack on Israel would be tantamount to one on Americans that would bring the United States into any military conflict. In return, Israel would agree to a final status accord with the Palestinians along the territorial lines that the U.S. has long endorsed: the 1967 borders with mutually agreed swaps. The U.S., working closely with Israel and Jordan, would not only help secure the partiesâ€™ safety, but work with European donors to put the new Palestinian state on a firm footing to reduce the possibility of revanchist violence. Under this arrangement, the U.S. would contemplate a military assistance package that came closer to Israelâ€™s vision for the one that has just been signed, while Israelâ€™s withdrawal from the West Bank would ensure robust trade ties with Europe well into the future. Many on both sides will say that this program entails too many risks for too uncertain a gain. Israelis for whom past is prologue will argue that the practical benefits of a treaty is available at no cost. It certainly doesnâ€™t fit with Donald Trumpâ€™s purely transactional view of international relations. But in an increasingly violent Middle East, it behooves both countries to reconsecrate a relationship based on a shared moral and strategic vision. As a matter of moral temperament and strategic vision, Hillary Clinton would appear far more likely to make this happen.

In an interview with theÂ Los Angeles Times, Galifianakis was asked if heÂ would haveÂ Republican nominee Donald Trump on his showÂ since his interview with Clinton was such a resounding successÂ â€“ and his answerÂ is hilarious. â€œNo. That doesnâ€™t interest me. NEW YORK â€” There's at least one Muslim country that Donald Trump has "great respect" for. The Republican presidential nominee Monday showered Egypt's increasingly autocratic ruler, Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, with kind words during a special meeting on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly. Story Continued Below Trump, who has called for a ban on immigration from countries "compromised by terrorism," which presumably would include Egypt, promised to invite Sisi to visit the White House if he's elected president. Trump also suggested he'd like to visit Egypt. In a strikingly praise-filled summary of the meeting released by his campaign, the Republican was said to express to Sisi "his strong support for Egyptâ€™s war on terrorism, and how under a Trump administration, the United States of America will be a loyal friend, not simply an ally, that Egypt can count on in the days and years ahead." Trump also was said to have "emphasized" to Sisi "his high regard for peace-loving Muslims." The statement came the same day that the real estate mogul, responding to a suspected terrorist attack in New York, lamented that police officers weren't allowed to use racial profiling. Sisi also met with Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton. Both the 2016 candidates have been criticized by people across the political spectrum for sparing any time for Sisi, whose harsh rule has infuriated human rights activists. But Egypt is still considered a vital ally for the United States, not least because it maintains a peace deal with Israel and is a relatively stable Arab country in an increasingly volatile Middle East. It also is considered an important partner in the battle against Islamist militancy. The meeting between Trump and Sisi also included Trump advisers, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) and retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn, former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency. According to the readout, Trump expressed "great respect for Egyptâ€™s history" and a "great fondness" for the Egyptian people. The readout did not say what Sisi said in return to Trump. Egyptian officials did not immediately respond to requests for comment Monday from POLITICO.

The scramble to cover-up the Hillary email scandal has come to light. The Platte River IT executives were not ignorant to what was going on. As Written By Isabel Vincent and Melissa Klein for The New York Post: Computers from China and Russia tried to attack Hillary Clintonâ€™s private e-mail server, according to never-released e-mails from the Denver company that set up and maintained the system. And other internal e-mails show the IT executives fretted about being ordered to purge e-mails and scrambled to distance themselves from what they believed was the former first lady â€œcovering up some shaddy [shady] s- -t.â€ In a gallows-humor message, one called it â€œHillaryâ€™s coverup operation.â€ The FBI in July chastised Clinton and her aides over the use of the private server, saying, â€œThey were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive, highly classified information.â€ But the agency declined to recommend charges. The internal communications also revealed how the execs belatedly tightened security on Clintonâ€™s now-controversial home server and frantically sought to â€œcover our assesâ€ when news broke that the former secretary of stateâ€™s communications were deleted. â€œAny chance you found an old e-mail with their directives to cut the backups back in Octâ€-Feb? . . . The Obama administration on Thursday terminated the federal recognition of the nation's largest accreditor of for-profit colleges â€” a rare move that could ultimately jeopardize the ability of hundreds of schools to access federal funding. The decision against the Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools amounts to what is effectively a death penalty. The sanction had been sought by prominent critics of for-profit colleges like Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who on Thursday called the accreditor a "negligent" organization that had "rubber-stamped shady institutions" for years. Story Continued Below The accreditor's seal of approval had allowed billions of dollars in taxpayer-funded Pell Grants and federal loans to flow to the now-defunct Corinthian Colleges chain of schools, which shut down last year amid allegations that it lured in prospective students using false, inflated job placement rates. ACICS was also the accreditor for ITT Tech, another troubled for-profit college that declared bankruptcy last week. The accreditor says that about 600,000 students across the country are enrolled at colleges that it approves. ACICS officials on Thursday pledged to appeal the decision directly to Education Secretary John B. King Jr. â€” a move that would temporarily put the termination on hold. Thereâ€™s no timeline for when King must act on that appeal, but earlier this week he pledged to get it â€œresolved quickly.â€ Roger Williams, the interim president of ACICS, said in a statement that the group was â€œdisappointedâ€ in the decision but â€œconfidentâ€ it could show â€œongoing progressâ€ toward coming into compliance with federal rules. If the Education Department stands by its decision, ACICS-accredited colleges would have 18 months to find a new accreditor, or else their students would lose access to federal money. Congress earlier this week passed legislation that allows GI Bill educational benefits to continue to flow to student veterans for up to 18 months after their schoolâ€™s accreditor loses its federal recognition. Like other college accreditors, ACICS acts as a gatekeeper for federal money: Last year, it allowed 243 colleges to tap into $4.76 billion worth of Pell Grants and federal student loans. The Obama administration's termination decision was based upon earlier Education Department findings that ACICS failed to properly monitor and discipline the colleges it oversees. â€œACICSâ€™s track record does not inspire confidence that it can address all of the problems effectively,â€ wrote Emma Vadehra, King's chief of staff, who issued the ruling. â€œMany of the problems identified in the staff report are serious and long-standing.â€ ACICS has been a prime target of for-profit critics and some Senate Democrats in recent years. Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.), on Thursday praised the administrationâ€™s decision in a statement, saying that â€œfar too many schools have maintained their institutional accreditation, even while defrauding and misleading students.â€ But Rep. John Kline (R-Minn.) blasted the Education Departmentâ€™s decision as â€œan unprecedented action that could disrupt the education of hundreds of thousands of students, particularly low-income and minority students.â€ The for-profit industry's trade association argued that the departmentâ€™s decision is yet another example of the unfair targeting of their industry by the Obama administration. "The U.S. Department of Education's decision today will have horrible ramifications for hundreds of thousands of students, thousands of dedicated faculty and staff, and hundreds of communities and employers that rely on institutions accredited by ACICS,â€ said Steve Gunderson, who leads the Career Education Colleges and Universities trade group. "No Administration has politicized accreditation like the current one.â€ Ben Miller, senior director of Postsecondary Education at the Center for American Progress, authored a report criticizing the record of ACICS that was frequently cited by a federal panel in making its recommendation to nix the accreditor. Miller praised Thursday's decision, calling it a "landmark step for protecting students and taxpayers." Terry Hartle, senior vice president at the American Council on Education, said schools without any red flags can probably find a new accreditor in one year to 18 months, but it could take two years or much longer for other schools to find a new home. â€œItâ€™s a major step,â€ Hartle said. â€œThe department has done it at least once before, but never with an accreditation agency of this size.â€ Kimberly Hefling contributed to this report.

Washington (CNN)Eric Trump on Friday defended his father's self-made real estate mogul narrative, saying the Republican presidential nominee was the epitome of the American dream for having "gone from just about nothing" to become a successful real estate mogul in New York. The younger Trump's comments follow extensive reporting of how the GOP presidential candidate got his start in property development in part thanks to a $1 million loan from his father, Fred Trump, in the late 1960s or early 1970s. "Well, I think he's a guy who has been an entrepreneurial guy," Eric Trump told Fox News on Friday after being asked about his father's outreach to millennial voters. "He's built an amazing company. He's become the epitome of the American dream." Trump begun to say that millennials could relate to his father because "he's gone from just about nothing," but was interrupted by "Outnumbered" panelist Julie Roginsky. "Nothing? He got a million bucks? I mean, come on," Roginsky interjected. "Listen, he's built an unbelievable empire," Trump responded. "He's epitomized what America is all about: opportunity and working hard and being able to achieve your dreams and what you want to succeed, right?" Trump continued, "It's no different from a (Mark) Zuckerberg, right, who went out with a great idea like Facebook and developed this idea and built it and grew it and grew it and grew it. That's achieving something, right? And I think it is very different than a person who has been career politician." In 2015, Donald Trump described the $1 million loan from his father as "small." "My whole life really has been a 'no' and I fought through it," Trump said at an NBC-sponsored town hall in October. "It has not been easy for me, it has not been easy for me. And you know I started off in Brooklyn, my father gave me a small loan of a million dollars." The 32-year-old Eric Trump on Friday also said that he thought millennials did not relate to policy well because "they haven't lived their lives long enough to understand ... the broad stroke of issues." "They obviously understand a lot of issues as it pertains to them, student debt, and this and that," Trump said. "But I think maybe taxes and things might be a little less significant than other issues. And so I just think there is a disconnect between somebody who is constantly talking about policy and this and that, than a man who's built a great company." Donald Trump's children have become prominent surrogates for his unconventional presidential campaign, but at times have cause minor controversies of their own. Eric Trump's comments come after his older brother, Donald Jr., caused controversy earlier this week when he likened Syrian refugees to Skittles.

Donald Trump's presidential transition operation has recruited GOP energy lobbyist Mike McKenna and vocal climate skeptic Myron Ebell to run teams focused on the Energy Department and EPA respectively, according to people familiar with the hires. David Bernhardt, the co-chair of the natural resources department at the firm Brownstein Hyatt Farber Schreck and a George W. Bush Interior Department official, is leading the transition's Interior Department team, sources said. Story Continued Below McKenna, is a well-connected energy lobbyist with ties to the industry-backed American Energy Alliance and Institute for Energy Research. McKenna has lobbied for the Dow Chemical Company, Southern Company and Koch Companies Public Sector, which terminated his contract in May, according to public records. According to his website, McKenna previously served as an "external relations specialist" at the Energy Department. Ebell is the director of the Center for Energy and Environment at the Competitive Enterprise Institute. He is a prominent skeptic of climate science and a regular critic of the Obama administration's environmental policies. But he has never worked at the EPA. Bernhardt, a veteran hand at Interior, served as deputy chief of staff and director of congressional and legislative affairs before becoming solicitor. His current lobbying clients, according to congressional disclosures, are the recreational company Active Network LLC and California's Westlands Water District. As POLITICO previously reported, veteran Capitol Hill aide Mike Catanzaro is helping to lead the transition's energy team. McKenna, Ebell and Bernhardt did not comment and the Trump campaign did not respond to a request for comment. E&E News first reported the hires.

North Carolina Republicans are lamenting the unrest gripping their stateâ€™s largest city, but, quietly, they also see it as an opportunity for Donald Trump to gain ground in a critical swing state. And theyâ€™re asking him to take advantage of it. Story Continued Below â€œNorth Carolina Republicans are sending the word to the Trump campaign that once this settles down, a visit to Charlotte, to the Mecklenburg police, to the sheriff and others, is something we really want to see,â€ said a high-ranking North Carolina Republican, granted anonymity to discuss political calculations during a sensitive moment for the state. â€œLawmakers and party officials are sending word to the Trump campaign.â€ The crisis in Charlotte was sparked by the shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, an African-American man who police say was armed, though no video has been released and the family disputes that claim. Since then, the city has been the scene of violent clashes between police and protesters, with the clashes captured on live, national television. The tumult comes as Hillary Clintonâ€™s once-formidable lead in state polls has faded. A spate of polls out this week show either a tied race or give Trump a slight edgeâ€”a sharp contrast from last month, when Clinton was leading by anywhere from 2 to 9 percentage points. North Carolina political operatives are skeptical that, unless the chaos in Charlotte continues for weeks, the issue will make a substantial dent in the race. But Republicans and some Democrats do say that the dynamic creates an opening for Trump to further shore up and energize the GOP baseâ€”something he has struggled to doâ€”predicting voters will respond to his campaignâ€™s law-and-order message and his staunch defense of police, even amid national concerns over institutional police racism. A senior adviser to the Trump campaign said only that Trump had been in the state earlier this week and "we have not yet announced the date of our next trip back to the state." â€œI certainly think unrest feeds into Trumpâ€™s narrative that â€˜Americaâ€™s falling apart, we need to make America great again,â€™â€ said Tom Jensen, a Democratic pollster whose firm is based in North Carolina. â€œMy sense is, most white North Carolinians who would be really repulsed by whatâ€™s going on in Charlotte would be in Trumpâ€™s camp. I doubt it moves the needle a lot, but the race is just about tied â€¦ something like that is never going to move the race by 3 or 4 points, but it can change the race on the margins, and weâ€™re on the margins.â€ Thus far, Clinton has largely stuck to tweeting in support of Scott, rather than commenting on the Wednesday night protests. And Trump was vague in a Fox News appearance Thursday morning, lamenting the â€œlack of spirit between the white and the black,â€ and going on to assert that amid the chaos â€œour country looks bad to the worldâ€ in a speech later in the day. But moving the needle even a little may be enough in a state where the polls are tight and thereâ€™s a history of thin margins. North Carolina, a typically red state that went for Barack Obama in 2008 before swinging back to support Mitt Romney in 2012, is central to Trumpâ€™s path to victory, which is narrower than Clintonâ€™s is. Clintonâ€™s summer leads in the state were fueled by support from African-American and college-educated voters in a state that is home to the Research Triangle, the Raleigh-Durham area where universities and high-tech companies are based. But in North Carolina, as in a number of other swing states, her lead has diminished amid scrutiny of her email practices, her health and her overall commitment to transparency. And the protests, Republicans say, may mean more trouble, especially if there are additional nights of strife. â€œEvery time there is a riot, protest, or general disruption of civility it helps Donald Trump,â€ said Chris Wilson, a Republican pollster who was the director of data, analytics and digital strategy on Ted Cruzâ€™s primary campaign. The Cruz primary campaign had firsthand experience with this: Protests at a Chicago Trump rally ahead of the March 15 primariesâ€”when a list of states that included North Carolina votedâ€”dominated the weekend coverage before those races. Wilson said the net effect was boosting Trump across the board in the final days before the Republican contests (though representatives from Sen. Marco Rubio's campaign, also watching their own internal numbers, have said they didnâ€™t see the same effect). â€œWe certainly saw this in the primaries as the riots [in] Chicago, prior to a scheduled Trump speech, created a significant lift for Trumpâ€™s candidacy,â€ Wilson said. â€œNot just in Illinois, but also in Missouri and North Carolina.â€ The unrest also carries risks for Trump, as the charged racial questions surrounding the issue heighten the possibility of a misstatement, one that could undo a recent effort to fight charges that heâ€™s a racist candidate. That is a risk for the bombastic Trump, who has a record of horrifying moderate voters in the wake of tragedies (â€œAppreciate the congrats for being right on radical Islamic terrorism,â€ he tweeted, following a shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, though he said he didnâ€™t want the â€œcongratsâ€). And the Charlotte situation carries opportunities for Clinton as well. African-Americans, a crucial part of her base, have been outraged by the shooting, the latest instance of a black man dying in an altercation with police (in this instance, the police officer involved was also African-American). Clinton has been a champion of â€œMothers of the Movement,â€ a group of African-American mothers whose children died primarily in incidents involving law enforcement, and she is a vocal proponent of criminal justice reform. In North Carolina and nationally, her campaign is engaged in extensive outreach to the African-American community. A senior Democratic operative working in North Carolina said the incidents unfolding in Charlotte underscore the risks African-Americans see in a potential President Trump. â€œIt is further alienation, a further concern among African-American voters about Trumpâ€™s presidency,â€ the source said, noting that Trump has a long record of making incendiary comments about minorities. The strategist said Trumpâ€™s best-case scenario, politically, is that calls for law and order help him solidify his baseâ€”but that doesnâ€™t move the dial with independent and more moderate voters, the source insisted. â€œI think Donald Trump continues to solidify his 43 percent of the vote, heâ€™s not adding votes, heâ€™s certainly alienating others,â€ the Democrat said, going on to add, â€œIt just confirms to his base all the things theyâ€™re concerned about are real. But shoring up 43 percent of the vote you have is not the way to get to 50.â€ And Carter Wrenn, a longtime Republican strategist, said it is not a given that Trumpâ€™s standing will rise on the other side of the aisle just because of the protests. â€œIf youâ€™re living in North Carolina, you turn on the TV and thereâ€™s riots in Charlotte, thereâ€™s looting, it gets your attention, but it doesnâ€™t automatically help one candidate over another,â€ he said. â€œIt depends on how the individual candidate responds. People will watch that. If they think, â€˜Gosh, Trumpâ€™s got a lot of judgment, he knows how to solve this,' it will help him. If they think, â€˜Old Trump just poured gas on the fire,â€™ it wonâ€™t help him at all.â€

There is a moment at every Donald Trump rally when Donald Trump marvels at the crazy spectacle heâ€™s created. â€œIs there any place in America as fun as a Donald Trump rally?â€ he asks with a mischievous pursed-lip grin. The moment always comes after a protester tries to interrupt him, only to be drowned out by an arena full of rowdy white people screaming â€œTRUMP! TRUMP! TRUMP!â€ Thatâ€™s the fun part, the joint release of pent-up fury by thousands of proudly politically incorrect Americans. When you experience it in person, you can feel their catharsis as they vent at the whiners and moochers and Mexicans and Muslims taking over their country, gleefully defying the scolds who call them racist and rude for respecting the police and saying Merry Christmas. â€œDonald Trump has singlehandedly untied our tongues,â€ a chain-saw artist named Chris Cox, the founder of Bikers 4 Trump, told me at a recent Pensacola rally. Story Continued Below When Trump fans are asked about his appeal, the first thing they usually say is that he isnâ€™t a normal politician. And his rambling, fear-mongering, name-calling public speeches, no matter how hard his new handlers try to keep him on his new teleprompter, do not feel like normal political events. They feel like Wrestlemania with a different kind of hero and a different kind of performance art. They feel like revival meetings for the Donald J. Trump Church of Cultural Resentment, with ritual denunciations of Crooked Hillary Clinton, Barack Obamaâ€”â€œWe call him President Obama, because we have to treat him with respect, right?â€â€”and other enemies of the congregation. At a time when Americans say theyâ€™re tired of politics as usual, Trump offers politics as deeply, often disturbingly, always unapologetically, unusual. His opponent does not. Clintonâ€™s events feel exactly like normal political events. She may be the worldâ€™s most famous and polarizing woman, but sheâ€™s running an almost generic Democratic campaign, politics as very usual. Tonight, Hillary Clinton will take on Donald Trump in perhaps the most anticipated presidential debate ever, a rhetorical clash of two candidates with diametrically opposed life histories, policy agendas, and bases of support. But their contrasting records and ideas havenâ€™t been the defining divides of this strange political year. What 2016 is really about is conventional versus not. And no matter what happens tonight, when you spend time at their diametrically opposed events, youâ€™re constantly reminded that what makes this year so abnormal is Trump. He is violating all the rules of the political gameâ€”rules that promote pandering and artifice as well as rules that promote transparency and decencyâ€”and when 2016 is over, itâ€™s not clear whether those rules will still apply. Whatever you think of Clinton, she tends to observe polite-society political traditions, which is why her events would feel familiar to anyone whoâ€™s attended a modern campaign stop. The backdrops are decorated with red-white-and-blue bunting and talking-point slogans like â€œLove Trumps Hateâ€ or â€œStronger Together.â€ The small venues are selected to target niche groupsâ€”millennials last week at Temple University in Philadelphia, the disabled a few days later at a family outreach center in Orlandoâ€”and the crowds are carefully curated to avoid protests or other surprises. The speeches are standard campaign fare, dotted with wonky statistics and real-person anecdotes to buttress well-researched policy proposals. The candidate, as she has for nearly four decades in public life, sticks to her prepared text. Her audiences are supportive, though not particularly emotive. â€œI thought it was very substantial, very specific,â€ Glenn McCoy, an adult educator at a Catholic church who wore a â€œHil Yes!â€ pin to Clintonâ€™s speech about supporting disabled workers in Orlando. â€œThe purpose wasnâ€™t to whip the crowd into a frenzy. Weâ€™re not looking to choose a president based on emotion.â€ Clinton had better hope not. Thereâ€™s electricity at Trump rallies that hers canâ€™t match. Itâ€™s no coincidence that cable news often ignores her speeches to carry the Trump shows live. His crowds wait with giddy anticipation for him to name and shame enemies, like NASCAR fans waiting for wrecks, and they explode when he calls out the dishonest media, the job-stealing Chinese, the PC sensitivity snobs who think youâ€™re prejudiced if you want to keep illegal immigrants and Islamic terrorists out of the country. Itâ€™s entertaining to watch him violate norms, declaring Clinton lacks the stamina to be president, suggesting her security detail ought to disarm, warning the election will probably be rigged. He flings out absurd claims about the skewing of the unemployment rate, the savagery of inner cities, even the temperature at his rallies. (â€œItâ€™s 100 degrees in here. And thatâ€™s considered cool for an auditorium.â€) He casually drops one outlandish bombshellâ€”the Federal Reserve is corrupt, the FBI is covering up for Clinton, NAFTA was the worst deal in the history of the worldâ€”then moves onto another before the last fully explodes. Clinton doesnâ€™t do that. Whatever one thinks about her email protocols or Benghazi or her penchant for secrecy, she campaigns like a typical candidate. She has the strengths and weaknesses of a typical public servant, and takes typical measures to try to frame them for the public. Her problem is that Trumpâ€™s unique combination of insult comedy and monster-truck rally, despite the flagrant abuse of facts and unsettling whiff of menace, is exposing the focus-grouped, stage-managed, paint-by-numbers nature of typical candidacies. Clinton isnâ€™t getting a lot of credit for following the rules of a game that always seemed inauthentic. Nobody understands that better than the political savant named Donald J. Trump. He tells a lot of straight-faced falsehoods about Clintonâ€™s campaign, like his accusations that itâ€™s â€œpolicy-free,â€ when he used to mock it for churning otut too many policy proposals, and when Trump himself recently laid off much of his policy shop. But thereâ€™s something to his caricature of Clinton events as the lackluster politics of yesteryear. At a rally in Miami, he did a sly imitation of Clinton's speechesâ€”he claimed with faux specificity that they're only 18 minutes, when they're usually twice that longâ€”with a bored expression that suggested she just phones them in. â€œBom. Bom. Bom. See ya!â€ Trump smirked. â€œSee ya! Iâ€™m going home.â€ Many Americans really do seem sick of Bom-Bom-Bom-See-Ya politics. But the live experience of Trumpâ€™s say-anything middle-finger alternative can be a bracing advertisement for the mundane traditions heâ€™s shredding every day. *** Before attending a recent Trump rally in Pensacola, I watched a video of his last rally there during the Republican primary in January. But starting with the Star Spangled Banner, performed by a kids group that later sued Trump for breach of contract, the entire rally seemed like a trip through the looking glass to an alternative political planet.
